Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Hey Colin, nice demos! 
>
Cheers. Although I feel slightly humbled by Tyler's 3D walker, not to 
mention the Natural Motion stuff. :)

>-Why is the default pmutate_add_connection setting at 77%?  That 
>seems extremeley high..so almost every mating leads to a new 
>connection?  
>
>  
>
>-Why is pmutate_connections_weights on the other hand at only 0.2?  
>Does that mean only 20% of matings have any mutation of weights?
>
>  
>
err, no that's not right, the two text boxes got switched around 
following a slight disaster in the form designer. So add_connection is 
at 20% and weight mutation at 77%, does that sound about right?

>-What is "elitism proportion?" The standard NEAT use of elitism is 
>to just keep one clone of the champ of every species that has been 
>alotted over 5 offspring in the next generation.  So it is species-
>based elitism.  But what does yours do?
>  
>

Not sure I follow there. Do you mean you take each species' best and 
create 5 offspring from it? or just keep it in the next gen unchanged?

SharpNeat also implements species based elitism. It's probably easiest 
to describe the whole process:

1) Using p_selection_proportion create a offspring per species and store 
them all in a seperate list away from the main population.
2) Cull the weakest n% of each species, where n = 100-p_elitism
3) Add the offspring into the population.
4) Back to 1

I happen to create precisely the correct amount of offsprng to make up 
for the genomes that are lost by the culling. So the population size 
remains constant(ish) - there is some variation because the size of each 
species is calculated indepedently and therefore you may get a few more 
or less offspring in the popualtion as a whole due to rounding.

Another point here is that you can choose to set p_elitism to be larger 
or smaller than p_selection_proportion. If you set it larger then you 
are creating offspring from the same set of elite genomes until some 
better genomes come along.  I do however sort the species by fitness and 
then by age, so older good genomes are more likely to be culled than new 
ones.

Also if eleitism is a very small value (or even 0) then I will always 
leave a minimum of 1 genome in a species. Therefore I think maybe that 
setting p_elitism to zero would make SharpNeat equivalent to origianl 
NEAT in this area.

>-The selection proportion of 0.1 is very low and will likely cause 
>premature convergence.
>  
>
Ok, I need to experiment with this value. What sort of range are people 
using?

>-My version of NEAT generally solves the single pole balancing 
>problem (with velocities) in under 1000 evaluations...so some of the 
>differences between the implementations probably are worth looking 
>into.  It looks like it takes maybe 10 times longer or more in 
>SharpNEAT.
>  
>

I have seen SharpNEAT spontaneously jump to a perfect solution after 
only 30 gens or so, but in general yes it can take a while.  I actually 
ported pole balancing precisely so that I could compare with origianl 
NEAT (I'll call it oNEAT for short), so this is good feedback. Also I'm 
going to try and compile NEAT here (thanks Darren) so I can make more 
detailed comparisons.

>-What is the weight mutation power and rate, i.e. how much do you 
>perturb weights and how likely is it any particular weight will be 
>perturbed?  Also, is there a max weight?
>  
>
Following your posting I did implement weight capping - currently set to 
+-3.0.

The weight mutation does currently differ from oNEAT.  I do use 
pColdGaussian /pGaussian roughly as in oNEAT. 10% of the time 30% of the 
weights are reset to random values (-3 to 3), but normally only 10% of 
weights are reset.

All of the of the other weights are 'jiggled', for this I use a function 
that generates numbers from a standard distribution curve. Currently I 
use a sigma of 0.025 which generates weight-delta's between about -0.1 
and 0.1, bu the bulk of the deltas are between +-0.05

Oh and in total only 20% of the weights in a genome affected, whereas I 
/think/ oNEAT mutates 100%.

Hope that all made sense, you did ask :) 

Colin.
